page.title: 03Nether Stowey: Old Features
page.content: At the lower end of Castle Street, the junction with Lime St. and St. Mary's St. is called The Cross. Its name derives from the old market cross which used to stand in the middle of the road for trading on Tuesdays. The bus shelter nearby used to be the village 'lockup'. When the cross was demolished the old clock and bell were incorporated in a new clock tower now standing by the bus shelter. The bell used to be tolled daily at 6am by the blacksmith's wife, but today it works mechanically. Along Lime St. is Coleridge Cottage. There are no lime trees there now, but when the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge lived here he called his house,"This Lime Tree Bower". The cottage is now owned by the National Trust and is open to the public. Coleridge Road commemorates him.
